With her delicious seasoning, she sells 'ceviche' (raw fish marinated in citrus juices and spiced with chili peppers) in the doorway of her house every morning and every afternoon she sells fritters such as 'salchipapas' (a Peruvian fast food made from thinly-sliced, pan-fried sausage or hot dog, french fries and condiments).

That isn't all.  Throughout these 5 years she has also been selling clothes which she gets from Tacna.  One of her sisters-in-law encouraged her to go into business and at 49 years old Luz has managed to extend her house and pay towards her (14 year-old) youngest child's school fees.  This loan will be invested in new merchandise such as toys and other products to sell this coming Christmas period.  Luz is proud that she can obtain loans from Edaprospo and pay them on time.

loans.use: To buy toys

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.en:
In 2002, Ricardo L. and his wife, Marielos, started screen-printing t-shirts in their garage for his father-in-law’s t-shirt business.  After a while, they decided to print custom t-shirts for other businesses.  One business asked them “do you do banners too?”  And they said “of course!” even though they hadn’t made banners before and did not have the necessary equipment. “Anytime they ask me something, I say ‘of course’ and I start doing it – and with a lot of success! … in that fashion, little by little, we grew.  That’s why they say that this is a good business.” 

Now they can print business cards in an hour or two.  “We’re very fast.  … We’ll stay up all night if we need to.  If we resolve our clients’ problems, they’ll return or recommend us.” It takes a while the first time they create a new product, though, because they have to buy materials and access machinery.  “My intention is to do everything in-house”.

Ricardo L. and his wife plan to use this loan to stock up on raw materials, such as rolls of vinyl or rolls of magnetic sheets to print on and cartridges of ink and toner for the machines. He always wants to have materials in stock so “I never have to think ‘I have to buy this, and that, and that.’  So I can think about service and quality - not spend my time on thinking ‘I have to buy’.  You just buy it and then you’re set.”

Without this loan, Ricardo thinks his business would continue to function, but it would have delayed their goals.  

Ricardo and his wife would like to be able to support more people.  “We want to give employment to people – to sustain many families.  That’s always what we’ve had in mind.  We don’t want to be rich; we would rather make it so people have something they can live off of.  We would also like to be very organized, and expand.  It’s been a dream for many years to have many offices in other cities.”

About two years ago, Ricardo and Marielos moved the business out of their garage.  “These have been the two most difficult years for the economy, but we’ve grown!  It’s a blessing for us.  The most difficult times are when you can put yourself to the test and prove your potential.”

That success is also passed on to his children. “I’m proud that people recognize my business every time as having high quality and good service. And of the lessons that it leaves for my children – it’s important.  When you have your own business, your horizon is very large.  Every day is an opportunity to do business.  And the children learn that way of thinking.”

Ricardo has three children. Ricky is in his third year of studying civil engineering, Odette plans to study architecture when she goes to college next year, and Dhais is in high school.

Born in Chicago, Ricardo grew up in Monterrey, Mexico.  He returned to the United States 11 years ago.

Ricardo describes himself as a very honest family man with a lot of faith. He said he “gives thanks to God for what I’m living.  That my business is successful.  That everything is going well with the business and with my marriage.”

Ricardo describes his marriage and business as “a partnership where each of us do what we know best how to do.  She knows how to manage money.  And I know well how to do the work with high quality.”

The advice Ricardo would like to give to other business owners is to “make the client feel like this business is for them; make them feel comfortable.  It doesn’t matter if the business is tiny or huge; treat them well.  You never know which small business will grow huge, and if you treat them well when they’re small they’ll stick with you.”

loans.use: To buy raw materials, such as rolls of vinyl, magnetic sheets, ink and toner

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes.

loans.name: Bolor-Erdene

texts.en:
Bolor-Erdene S. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Hovd province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in their own house with fence. His two children both attend a local secondary school. 

Bolor-Erdene operates a meat-trading business in his town with help of his wife. He started his own business in 2003 by operating a raw-material trading business with help of his brother-in-law. After several years of operation, he has managed to establish himself in the business community and his business earnings have enabled him to buy a mini truck for his business. They travel thorough the countryside to purchase raw materials and exchange those products for foodstuffs. For the future, he plans to purchase more products in order to expand his sales. 

Bolor-Erdene says, "I want to remodel my house, but I travel through (the) countryside a lot; therefore, I don't have much time to improve my house." He is requesting a 2,600,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) loan in order to purchase more livestock skins and wool as well as livestock and meats from herders for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more livestock skins and wool

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene C. is from the village of Oroquieta City. She is 36 years old. Irene is single and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Irene owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating motor transport services. Irene has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Irene joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Irene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from GDMPC. Irene is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to repair existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Irene from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Tarcisia

texts.en:
As Sophocles said, no man loves life like he who is growing old. At 61, Tarcisia O. cannot have loved life more. Tarsing, as she is called by family and friends, did not even manage to finish high school, but has gone far in life. At present she attends fellowships in CCT as a Community Partner and enjoys the company of her grandchildren as she lives in Bagong Silang, a barangay of Caloocan City located on the islands of Luzon.

Tarsing sells vegetables, meat, fish, and fruits to the community and has become an advocate for healthy eating by doing so. She starts early in the morning, offering products that are fresh and healthy. Every month, she earns an estimated net income of around 10,000 PHP.

To help her grow her business, Tarcisia is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this to buy more fresh supplies of meat and vegetables as well as fish and fruits. She will make sure that her products are not only fresh, but that they are also varied so as to allow more options for her customers. Tarsing also intends to add frozen foods to her goods for sale.

As a local vender, Tarsing feels the weight of exhaustion and lack of sleep. Nevertheless, she is always ready to serve her fellow community members by offering and encouraging them to buy healthy foods. She wants her business to become well established and have more regular customers. She looks forward to abundant blessings from the Lord so that she may be able to help her grandchildren.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends their weekly fellowship meetings where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missionary work in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

Locally, all CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh vegetables, fruits and fish to sell

loans.name: Clementine

texts.fr:
Commerçante de 60 ans, divorcée avec 8 enfants a sa charge dont l'age varie entre 20 et 41 ans. En 1980 , elle se lance dans la vente de la layette pour subvenir aux différents charge qui lui incombe pour élever ses enfants.
Avec son premier prêt elle a fait acheter de la marchandise aux commerçantes qui viennent de Kinshasa,Cotonou et de la Chine, elle a fait des ventes de 25000 fr a 60.000frs par jour a beaucoup épargne et a rembourse son prêt sans trop de difficultés.
Vu l'expérience acquise , elle veut persévérer pour l'octroi d'un autre prêt,renforcer son stock et élargir ses étalages de ventes pour que sa fille l'aide pour vendre au marche. 
Tres entreprenante, elle a l'intention d'aller elle même acheter a l'étranger comme font les autres pour qu'elle soit grossiste .
texts.en:
Clémentine N., age 60, is a merchant. She's divorced and has eight children (aged 20 to 41) to support. In 1980, she started selling layettes in order to be able to raise her children. She used her first loan to buy supplies from Kinshasa, Cotonou and China. She sold for XOF 25'000 to 60'000 per day and managed to put away a large sum. She repaid her loan without much difficulty.

Considering the experience she acquired, she wants to seek another loan, to bolster her stock and expand her selling stalls, so that her daughter can help her with the sales at the market. A true entrepreneur, she intends to travel abroad herself to get her supplies and become a wholesaler.

loans.use: To buy diapers, brassieres, blankets, feeding bottles, sheets, drawsheets

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie V. is from the village of Brgy. Lamo, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 40 years old, married, and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosemarie owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Rosemarie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the food she sells. This will be Rosemarie’s 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her immediate family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisher-folk and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the food she sells

location.town: Brgy. Lamo, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Priel

texts.en:
For reasons of modesty, Priel's son is pictured in the photo. Priel is a 43-year-old mother of seven with an elementary school education. She worked as a part-time helper in daycare centers but wanted to create a better future and decided she could create more income through her own business. She began selling household supplies and basic amenities. Eventually, through training and support, she opened a small minimarket at her home.

Priel needed the loan to increase her store's supplies and buy stock including dry goods, perishables, drinks and specialty items her customers wanted.

Priel dreams of expanding her minimarket and one day opening a supermarket that is sorely needed in her neighborhood.

loans.use: to increase her store's supplies and buy stock

loans.name: Umar

texts.en: This is 37 year-old Umar. He is married, and has one child, aged 6. In 2008, Umar established his timber business. He began his business because he was inspired by a brother in the village to start the business.  He says, "I tried it and it works.  Now I am benefitting alot from this timber business."  Working 7 days a week and 9 hours a day, he earns about Le 500,000 every month. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000 in order to purchase more wood. In the future, Umar plans to acquire a brand new power saw so that he can also produce wood.  He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more timber for his business

loans.name: Juliana Antonia

texts.es: Juliana Antonia se dedica a la venta de refrescos y gaseosas. Tiene más de 4 años con su actividad. Es una persona muy trabajadora y disfruta mucho de su hablar con sus clientes, pues sabe que tiene un ingreso que le genera el pan de cada día. Inicio con esfuerzo propio, ya que ella solo tenía el apoyo de 3 de sus hijos mayores, que le ayudaron a establecer este negocio. Todos los días e levanta temprano para empezar con la preparación de sus refrescos como limonada, naranja, melón, mandarina, cacao entre otros productos. El financiamiento es para la compra de frutas para la elaboración de sus refrescos y la compra de gaseosas.  Ella sueña con proporcionarle mejoras a su vivienda y brindar a su familia una mejor estabilidad.
texts.en: Juliana Antonia sells carbonated and non-carbonated soft drinks and has been doing this for four years.  She is a hard working woman who enjoys talking to her customers and knows that her business helps her earn her daily bread.  She began on her own because she only had the support of her three young children who helped her start her business.  She rises early each day to prepare her drinks of different flavors, like lemon, orange, cantaloupe, mandarin orange, chocolate, and others.  She will use the money for this loan to buy fruit and carbonated drinks.  She wants to make improvements to her home and provide better stability to her family.

loans.use: to buy fruits to make drinks

loans.name: Angelique

texts.en: Angelique is 32 years old, with 5 children between the ages of 10 and 2 years old. Her husband is a farmer and they are both hardworking. Angelique has been selling banana juice for 3 years. She is requesting a loan to buy more banana juice. She hopes to use the profits to buy more equipment for her business.

loans.use: to buy banana juice for sale

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John G. is a 26-year-old single businessman. He has been running his motorcycle transport business for a period of two years and earns an income of 10,000 Kenyan shillings a month.

This is John's first loan from KADET LTD.  He wants to use it to buy a piece of land. He hopes to own rental houses and improve his living standards.

loans.use: to buy a piece of land

loans.name: Monica Santos

texts.es:
Mónica es una mdare de familia de 39 años de edad,  tiene casa propia donde vive con su esposo e hijos, no cuenta con servicio básicos, ubicada en el caserío los Aguilares  que pertenece al distrito de Pítipo que se encuentra en la Provincia de Chiclayo.  Esta zona se dedica a la agricultura  y ganadería.

Mónica se dedica a la crianza y venta de aves de corral (gallinas, patos y  pavos), su corral donde viven sus animales se encuentra en la parte externa de su casa, los alimenta con dieta balanceada y granos naturales.  Posteriormente vende sus animales una vez que hayan llegado a su tamaño y peso ideal en los diferentes mercados de la ciudad de Chiclayo;  incrementando sus ingresos y obteniendo  cosas que le hacen falta en su hogar.  También cuenta con una pequeña tienda en su casa, ya que en el caserío donde vive no hay, lo que le permite tener otro ingreso económico.


El crédito que ha solicitado  es de 1200 nuevos soles a Edpyme  Alternativa mediante Capital Semilla, el cual será destinado  para la compra de aves de corral y algunos productos para abastecer su tienda para y así poder pagar su préstamo, lo que le ayudara  a mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.  Mónica es una persona trabajadora y con mucho empeñosa  a sabido salir adelante para mejorar en su negocio y como familia.
texts.en:
Mónica is a 39 year-old mother who lives in her own home together with her husband and children.  Her home does not have basic services and is located in the small village of Los Aguilares, in Pítipo district, in Chiclayo province.  The people in this area farm and raise livestock.

Mónica raises and sells poultry (hens, ducks and turkeys).  The pen where she keeps her animals is located outside her home.  She feeds her animals a balanced diet and natural grains.  She then sells her animals in the different markets in the city of Chiclayo once they have reached an ideal size and weight.  This increases her profits and she is able to obtain things that her household lacks.  Mónica also has a small store in her home since there isn't one in the village where she lives.  This makes her another income.

Mónica has requested a loan for 1,200 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa through their seed fund.  She will use this money to buy poultry and some products with which to stock her store.  This will enable her to repay her loan and improve her family's quality of life.  Mónica is a hard-working person with a lot of drive who has known how to get ahead in order to improve her business and also her family life.

loans.use: to buy poultry and some products with which to stock her store

loans.name: Tattygul's Group

texts.en:
Tattygul, 24, is the leader of this group. Despite being younger than the other members, she expressed a wish to lead the group. Tattygul is the young mother of two children, the oldest being three. Five years ago, following her husband’s initiative, she purchased her first livestock for 15,000 soms. She took good care of them, feeding and watering them, before further reselling in a farm yard. Her parents try to help her run the business, along with taking care of her children. The monthly income reaches 10,000 soms. Tattygul has applied for a loan from Kiva to buy more livestock. She thanks all Kiva lenders for this significant help.

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Nazareth De Jesus

texts.es: Nazareth De Jesús tiene 20 años, su actividad es la venta de refrescos, helados y gaseosas. Inicio este negocio hace 2 años, por su Mama quien anteriormente se hacía cargo, pero con el paso del tiempo es que Nazareth logro hacerse cargo de la actividad. Es una persona muy carismática, que tiene todas las ganas de salir adelante. El motivo del crédito es para la compra de gaseosas, golosinas, refrescos y otros productos la mayoría de sus clientes siempre le solicitan variedad.
texts.en: Nazareth De Jesús is 20 years old and sells softdrinks, icecream and sodas.  She began this business two years ago after gradually taking it over from her mother who was in charge before.  She is very charismatic and intent on getting ahead.  The loan will be used to buy sodas, sweets, softdrinks and other products, since the majority of her customers always want variety.

loans.use: To sodas, sweets, softdrinks and other items.

loans.name: Soledad

texts.es: Soledad es socia del Banco Comunal Despertar, tiene 57 años, es casada con dos hijos, tiene un hospedaje en el cercado D. Ayacucho y dos puestos D. comida en el mercado D. Santa Elena. El préstamo que solicita lo destinará para el arreglo D. sus puestos que están descampados antes le habían asignado otros puestos pero los reubicaron D. nuevo, ahora D. nuevo tiene que comenzar a realizar algunos arreglos, le agrada FINCA Perú, por la facilidad en los créditos y el apoyo con las capacitaciones que reciben, está ya 4 años, se pasa momentos bonitos con las compañeras D. su banco es una manera D. relajarse, con sus ahorros fue implementando sus puestos, se compró su refrigeradora y algunas cosas que necesitaba. Su sueño es seguir prosperando.
texts.en: Soledad is a member of the communal bank Despertar. She is 57 years old and is married, with two children. She has a hostel in the Ayacucho district and two food stalls in the Santa Elena market. The loan that she is applying for is destined for setting up her stalls, which are out in the open. In the past, they assigned her other stalls, but they relocated them again, and now she has to begin arranging them again. She is pleased with FINCA Peru for the ease of obtaining loans and for the support and the training they receive. She has already been in the communal bank for 4 years, and she has a pleasant time with her fellow bank members. It is a way to relax. She set up her stalls with her savings. She bought a refrigerator and some things that she needed. Her dream is to continue prospering.

loans.use: to set up her food stalls.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua sells maize at the Elmina market for a living. She has been selling maize for eight years. She pays the family's utility bills, school fees for her four children, and accommodation costs with the income she makes from her business. 

Ekua's loan will be used to buy more sacks of maize. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to ensure the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of maize to offer for sale

loans.name: Rosa Aminta

texts.es:
Rosa, se dedica a la venta de queso, ella vive con sus hijos, ella tiene el negocio de la venta de queso en su vivienda este es hereditario, también vende tortillas, de estos dos negocios ha logrado mantener a su familia y hoy en día necesita financiamiento para comprar maíz y leña para la elaboración de tortillas.
Este préstamo le ayudara para contar con los materiales necesarios para darle continuidad al negocio, manteniendo siempre las ventas a los clientes frecuentes.
Su objetivo es mejorar cada día, teniendo esta fuente de ingreso para solventar las necesidades más prioritarias de su hogar.
texts.en: Rosa sells cheese.  She lives with her children.  She has a home-based cheese selling business that was passed down from her parents.  She also sells tortillas.  These two businesses make it possible for her to support her family and presently she needs a loan to buy corn and firewood to make tortillas. This loan will help her have the necessary raw materials on hand to give her business continuity keeping sales up with her regular customers. Her objective is to improve each day having this source of income to meet the most pressing needs in her home.

loans.use: to buy corn and firewood to make tortillas.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
Lucia  D. 59 años D. edad, vive con su esposo en su casa propia, cuenta con servicio D. agua y luz, ubicada en la zona urbana del distrito D. Patapo que pertenece a la provincia D. Chiclayo.  Esta zona se caracteriza por la actividad agrícola y ganadera.

DesD. hace unos 3 años aproximadamente Lucia se ha dedicado a la venta D. abarrotes (productos que se utilizan diariamente como: leche, arroz, aceite, azúcar, papel higiénico, atún, huevos,etc), útiles D. escritorio y D. bebidas, su negocio lo ha colocado en su misma casa para su comodidad y seguridad, con las ganancias por la venta D. sus productos  trata D. cubrir  todos sus gastos y mejorar su nivel D. vida.

Para poder  implementar su negocio a solicitado un crédito a Edpyme Alternativa  D. 2000 nuevos soles para comprar más mercaderías, con el único ideal D. que su negocio crezca y tenga más productos para ofrecerles a sus clientes;  para cubrir su préstamo y sus obligaciones D. su casa.  Lucia es una persona responsable, dedicada y trabajadora que se preocupa por tener más comodidades para su esposo y ella.
texts.en:
Lucia is 59 years old.  She owns the home where she lives with her husband.  The house has electricity and running water.  It is located in an urban neighborhood in Patapo, in the Chiclayo province.  This area is known for agricultural and ranching activities.  

For approximately the last 3 years, Lucia has sold groceries (daily use products such as milk, rice, cooking oil, sugar, toilet paper, tuna, eggs, etc.), stationery goods, and drinks.  Her business is located in her own home for her confort and safety.  The earnings from the sales of her products are used to try to cover her expenses and improve her quality of life. 

To stock her store, Lucia is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa for 2000 new soles, which will be used to purchase more merchandise.  Her only goal is to grow her business and have more products to offer customers, in order to pay off her loan and her household obligations.  

Lucia is a responsible person, dedicated and hard-working, who works to have more comforts for herself and her husband.

loans.use: to purchase more merchandise to stock her store.

loans.name: Fathiya

texts.en:
Fathiya is a 33-year-old housewife married to Nader, a mini-market owner.
 
To be able to support their five children, they decided to work together by opening a mini-market last year in al Wihdat. They started small and through the last year, they were able to fill the shop with the most wanted items.

Now Fathiya has applied for a loan to give her husband more support and buy more items that are requested by their customers, and expand their business to become a super market in the future.

Fathiya is a conservative person who preferred that her husband Nader appear in the photo instead.

loans.use: To buy more food items requested by his customers

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 16 years.  He is 43 years old, married to Nyambura, and they have five school-going children.  

He was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy seeds and fertilizer.

In future, Julius hopes to become one of the leading farmers in Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.es: La Sra. Rosario se dedica a la venta de desayunos, ella es una persona que ha aprendido la actividad de su madre que trabajo en el mercado ramada por más de 20 años, ella le enseño el oficio,  La Sra. Rosario cuenta con puesto propio y vende desayunos todo el día. Los productos que ofrece son te, café, api y empanada, la Sra. Rosario cuenta con 4 hijos ella es madre soltera, por cosas del destino, pero ella es valiente y trabaja duro para sacar a sus hijos adelante,  Tres hijos estudian en la escuela y uno es menor de edad. El crédito que esta solicitando es para la compra de material de construcción para culminar la construcción de su vivienda. Su aspiración es tener su propia movilidad para poder trasladar su mercadería y su deseo es el de ver a sus hijos profesionales y convertirse en personas de bien.
texts.en:
Rosario sells breakfast.  She learned this work from her mother, who worked in the Ramada Market for more than 20 years and taught her the trade.  Rosario has her own stall and sells breakfast all day.  The products she offers are tea, coffee, "api" (a Bolivian breakfast drink made of corn), and turnovers.

Rosario has four children.  As fate would have it, she is a single mother.  But she is courageous and works hard to get her children ahead.  Three of her children are students and one is a minor.

The loan she is requesting is to buy construction materials to finish the construction on her home.  Her ambition is to have her own vehicle to be able to move her merchandise, and her desire is to see her children become professionals and honest people.

loans.use: to buy construction materials.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.es:
La señora Patricia es una mujer soltera de 45 años de edad madre de 3 hijos mayores de edad, una señora que apesar de que sufrio mucho maltrato con el padre de sus hijos pudo salir adelante tener su casita y generar ingresos por ella misma, es una señora muy trabajadora, luchadora que desde hace cuatro años se dedica al negocio ella empezo vendiendo bisutería , ella se entero de la Fundación Por medio de otra clienta de la Fundación es su primer crédito , aparte de la venta por catalogo también hace artesanía en barro y cerámica para vender. 

La clienta Desde hace cuatro años se dedica a la venta por catalogo nos dice que les ha ido muy bien tambien va y compra ropa y la vende, en su casa tiene en el patio un cuarto pequeño donde guarda sus material para hacer artesanias en barro y ceramica ,ella con el préstamo piensa invertir en la compra de mercaderia para sus ventas por catalogos, ya que tiene varios pedidos y por falta de capital no ha podido traerlos  

Ella poco a poco empezo a capacitarse para trabajar la artesania a la fecha de voy vende artesanía el cuarto que tiene lo mantiene ordenado y limpio ya que ahí es donde sus clientas y clientes van y ven su material y ella de una vez ofrece los catalogos.
 
Doña Patricia se levanta muy temprano hace las labores domesticas y durante el dia cobra vende y en la noche pinta sus artesanias, es una mujer que con su esfuerzo a salido adelante y el capacitarse le ha ayudado a  conocerse y tener un mejor autoestima con este crédito la señora podrá  tener mas capital para seguir vendiendo
texts.en:
Señora Patricia is a single 45-year-old woman.  She has three grown children.  In spite of the fact that she suffered a great deal of mistreatment from the father of her children, she has been able to make progress, and to have her own little house and make her own income.  She is a very hardworking and determined woman.  Four years ago, she started her own business selling jewelry. She found out about the Foundation through another borrower.  This is her first loan.  Apart from selling jewelry and catalogue items, she also makes clay crafts and ceramics to sell.

For the past four years she has been selling items from catalogues.  She tells us that this has gone very well, and that she also buys clothes and resells them.  In the patio of her house she has a small room where she keeps her materials to make her clay and ceramic crafts.  She intends to invest the funds from this loan in merchandise for her catalogue sales, since she has a number of orders and for lack of capital has not been able to fulfill them.

Little by little she has taught herself how to make the crafts that she makes today.  She sells her crafts from the room that she has.  She keeps it orderly and clean since this is where her customers come and see her crafts and the items she offers from the catalogues.

Patricia gets up very early.   She does her household chores, and during the day she sells her merchandise, and at night she paints her crafts.  She is a woman who has made great progress through her own efforts.  The process of teaching herself has taught her about herself and has helped to improve her self-esteem.  With this loan she will have more capital to be able to continue selling her products.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to build her inventory of clothes, perfume and cosmetics.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a forty-five-year-old married woman with eight school-going children. Her husband Hare is a retired teacher who contributes to the provision of  basic family needs. She has a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for her family and school fees for her children. 

Josephine has operated a green grocery for the past fifteen years; her potential clients are her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of transporting her goods from the market to her sales point. She dreams of having a wholesale grocery shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase vegetables for her business. She decided to join Yehu because it understands its clients' needs.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables for her business.

loans.name: Primitiva

texts.en:
Primitiva  is 66 years old, widowed, and has four adult children.  She is from Poblacion 1 Clarin Misamis Occidental, Philippines. To make a living, Primitiva owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She earns 5,000 PHP a month and has been in this business for five years. 

Primitiva has been a member of GDMPC for almost six years. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC.  Primitiva is requesting a new loan for 20,000 PHP,  which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. In the future, Primitiva's plans to renovate their house.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Ganbaatar

texts.en:
Ganbaatar is 53 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent, in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Since 1974, Ganbaatar has been working as a welder and he opened his own home welding business in 2005. His wife and daughter help with his business and his son works in city. Ganbaatar is well known for his excellent work and his equipment is portable equipment which gives him an advantage over his competitors. 

Ganbaatar recently received a mass order from a company and he is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to buy thin and thick iron.

loans.use: to buy iron

loans.name: Yuri

texts.es:
Yuri de 26 años, hace 10 años convive con su pareja, con quien tiene 4 hijos de 11, 8, 5 y 3 años. Ellos viven en una casa propia en la comunidad nativa San Pablo de Shaoriato. Yuri desde niño se dedica  a las labores del campo. La agricultura es la actividad en la que se desenvuelve con libertad y sabiduría. Gracias a la fertilidad de los suelos y a la destreza en los negocios, está convencido de que saldrá adelante. En las 2 hectáreas de terrenos de su propiedad cultiva kión y en otras 2 café.  “Depende de cómo negocies, por ejemplo el café es más rentable en mayo y abril. El kión en estos meses, no me puedo quejar”, explica. Además comenta que falta de capital fue uno de sus problemas principales para invertir en el pago de operarios. “Pago 15 soles para el macheteo (corte de maleza con el machete), 18 soles para la siembra y 25 para la limpieza del kión”, manifiesta.
Yuri espera ampliar su casa con la construcción de más cuartos, para ello seguirá trabajando igual o más que ahora. Esta sería la primera vez que Yuri contaría con un préstamo de MFP, se compromete a ser puntual en los pagos. En cuanto a su banco comunal:”San Pablo Shima”, se siente contento por que dentro del grupo encuentra amigos confiables. Con el dinero del crédito podrá continuar con las siembras. Invertirá en el pago de personal contratado y algunas bolsas de abonos.
texts.en: Yuri is 26 years old and has been married to his wife for the 10 years. They have four children, ages 11, 8, 5 and 3, and they all live in a home they own in the community of San Pablo de Shaoriato. Since he was a young boy Yuri has made a living working in the fields. Agriculture has given him his freedom and his wisdom. Thanks to the fertility of the soil and his knowledge of the business, he was convinced he could get ahead. He owns two hectares of land on which he cultivates ginger, and has two other hectares where he cultivates coffee. "It depends on the business," he says. "For example coffee is more profitable in May and April. Ginger during these months, I can't complain." Furthermore, he says that a lack of capital is one of biggest problems in investing in his business. "I pay 15 soles for cutting weeds with a machete, 18 for planting and 25 for cleaning the ginger," he says. Yuri wants to expand his house by adding more rooms, and to do that he will keeping working just as hard or even harder. This is his first loan with Kiva partner MFP, and he promises to be punctual with his payments. In his community bank, "San Pablo Shima", he feels content to be part of a group of trustworthy friends. With the money he is requesting, he will be able to continue his planting by hiring workers and buying some sacks of fertilizer.

loans.use: to hire workers and buy sacks of fertilizer.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
This is Grace, 58, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. Her husband, Alejandro, is her business partner, and father to her three children. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Grace operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Aside from this she also oversees their Jeepney unit (a public utility vehicle) that gives them additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 26,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Grace hopes her business grows in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy piglets

loans.name: Tayson Group

texts.es:
El grupo Tayson lo conforman  tres personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras una de ellas es Cecilia del Carmen  quien es la coordinadora del grupo propietaria de una pulpería la cual inicio con 50 dólares y poco a poco fue aumentándola.  El crédito lo invertirá en productos (granos básicos, carne, productos lácteos…etc.) para mejorar su negocio.
Las otras integrantes son Maribel de 47 años quien se dedica al comercio de frutas y verduras desde hace 25 años y Juana Bertilda quien es costurera desde hace 30 años.
texts.en: The Tayson Communal Bank is made up of three hardworking and enterprising people, one of whom is Cecilia del Carmen who is coordinator of the ownership group of a grocery store, which she started with 50 dollars and gradually expanded. She will invest the loan in products (basic grains, meat, dairy products, etc) in order to improve her business. The other members of the communal bank are Maribel, 47, who has been selling fruits and vegetables for 25 years and Juana Bertilda, who has been a seamstress for 30 years.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, meat, dairy products

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa has produced kenkey (corn flour dumplings) to sell at the village of Akotokyire near Abura for the past 3 years. She is married with 6 dependents. Her husband is a security officer. Adjoa uses her income to assist her husband in the upkeep of their children. She needs this loan to purchase maize in bulk for her kenkey production. With the new profit, Adjoa wishes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize in bulk for her kenkey.
